content.webTitle: Digital masters: how new initiatives equalise women in sound

fields.headline: Digital masters: how new initiatives equalise women in sound
fields.bodyText: When most people think of a sound engineer, the person that springs to mind is a man: be it in a recording studio or behind the sound desk at a live performance. Even the language used is often gendered: “the sound guy”. Technical roles in music in general – producers and mixers, for example – are almost always perceived as the realm of men. Like most stereotypes, this has a basis in fact – in both North America and the UK, for example, it’s a regularly repeated statistic that less than 5% of audio engineers are women. Unfortunately, this is not a number that has changed with any great significance over the past two decades. So what is it about music tech that makes the numbers so strikingly disparate between men and women? In part, it might well be a self-fulfilling stereotype. Firstly, a lack of representation might make it seem an impossible pursuit. Marta Salogni is a professional sound engineer, producer and mixer, whose body of work includes recordings with the likes of The xx, Frank Ocean and Björk. Now based in London, it was back in her village in Lombardy, Italy, aged 16, when she became fascinated with the concept of sound engineering. “It made me a little bit scared because I couldn’t cling on to any role model – there was no one to demonstrate that that career was possible, and I felt alone a lot of the time.” In turn, she says, this may have been what pushed her to find other people like her, and to succeed so that it became more normal to see women in these spaces. It’s been a fruitful pursuit – Salogni is one of the most high-profile women in the field in Europe, and yet she finds this a strange position to be in. “Going into this profession knowing you’re going to be unique means you’re put under a spotlight automatically,” she sighs. “Being told: ‘Oh, I’ve never worked with a woman before’ doesn’t feel like a compliment – it just makes me feel like I have to do a lot of work to rebalance this whole mess.” Salogni also says the concept of what a recording studio used to be like at the height of rock’n’roll patriarchy (“a sexist man cave”) can still affect the dynamic, not only in terms of how she feels in that space, but how she is perceived there – she notes that if women are expecting to feel uncomfortable in a space, then not all of them are going to be up for fighting to be there. “People have come to the studio, they’ll look around and try to understand why I’m there, what my role could be. And you can feel that on yourself, obviously – that person is doubting you,” Salogni says. “Subconsciously, I hold on to that prejudice – I used to be really worried people would come into the studio and think I was not good enough, because I am a woman, or that I’m not in charge, because I’m a woman.” While representation is important, waiting on meritocracy isn’t enough to redress the balance, Salogni says, alluding to the necessity for positive discrimination. More and more schemes are coming into place to try to make this a reality – Spotify launched the EQL Directory in association with organisation SoundGirls last year, providing a list of women and gender non-conforming audio professionals. It is, as SoundGirls say on their website, “a useful tool when people say ‘they want to hire women but can’t find any.’” Then there are organisations such as Saffron – a Bristol-based group that’s part record label and part educational facility for women, founded by Laura Lewis-Paul in 2015. Among other things, Saffron runs “Saffron For Sound”, women-only courses in partnership with dBs – a local music college – teaching about music production software such as Ableton and Logic, as well as studio engineering. Lizzy Ellis from the organisation explains: “When I did music tech at college, I was the only girl in the class – so I think we’ve certainly managed to create an environment that’s much less intimidating for women, that’s accepting people wherever they’re at.” In addition to the issues of representation and a potential lack of respect from men in the industry, Ellis posits that jobs in sound engineering can often require “unsociable and long hours”, especially for those working in the live arena who might be on touring crews for long periods of time. “It doesn’t sit with the standard idea of a family setup for women – which shouldn’t make a difference, but, unfortunately, it often does. That’s part of a much wider conversation, obviously.” Both Salogni and Ellis are also aware that the push for inclusivity in the audiosphere needs to go beyond talking about women, too – no statistics exist specifically breaking down the number of black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) and/or working class women in these spaces, but Salogni notes the space is one dominated by “middle-class white people”. For now, hopefully initiatives such as Spotify and SoundGirls’ EQL Directory, development platforms such as Saffron, and women dominating in the field can help push the conversation forward. The 5% statistic is one that Salogni laughs off – she’s heard it so many times. “Hopefully in 10 years’ time, we’ll be closer to 50-50 and women won’t have to do interviews about this any more.” Everything you need to know about sound engineering Sound engineering is the process by which all the elements of audio or a live performance are recorded and/or pieced together to sound as refined as possible: so that’s everything from knowing the acoustics of a room, to deciding on the levels, knowing which microphones to use and where best to place them. Producing was once a very separate role from engineering but, increasingly, it now crosses over. Producers work with the artist on the track in a less technical way, helping to make the artistic choices – so it’s making the track the best it can be, but on a compositional level. For example, choosing the instrument that might sound best, suggesting a different song structure, and coaxing the best performance out of an artist. Often, sound engineers are also the mixers – although this too can be a separate job. Mixing is the final stage – once the recording is finished, the mixer will take the files, or the tape, and create a balanced composition. So, say there were nine microphones recording one guitar, the mixer would have to take these nine different recordings and mix them together, and then – depending on what the composition calls for – mix in the other instruments, vocals, etc. They are also in charge of making the choices on volume levels and additional effects. If you’ve watched Netflix documentary The Defiant Ones, you will be aware there was once a time when simply being available at all hours and learning by practising was how you became a sound engineer. Nowadays, things are very different – in most cases, specific training is required in the appropriate technology and software (Pro Tools, for example), be that in a higher education institution or an apprenticeship scheme. According to PayScale, the average salary for a sound engineer is £25,000 per annum, with stats suggesting the gender divide is now 95% men and 5% women.
